headline: Why Estée Lauder (EL) Shares Are Trading Lower Today
summary: Shares of beauty products company Estée Lauder (NYSE:EL) fell 4.9% in the afternoon session after the company reported a sharp decline in sales for its fourth quarter and provided a weaker-than-expected forecast for the upcoming fiscal year. Revenue for the quarter fell 11.9% year on year to $3.41 billion, meeting Wall Street’s expectations. However, other key metrics disappointed investors. headline: Estee Lauder Outlook Disappoints as Losses Widen
summary: Estee Lauder  widened its loss in its fiscal fourth quarter as sales continued to struggle, and it issued a dismal full-year outlook.  The beauty company behind MAC, Smashbox and Jo Malone, said Wednesday that costs tied to tariffs are projected to ding earnings by $100 million in its current fiscal year.  Estee Lauder added it will try to offset “more than half” of the levies by leveraging trade programs and optimizing its supply chain.

raw.headline: Estee Lauder Outlook Disappoints as Losses Widen

The beauty company behind MAC, Smashbox and Jo Malone, said Wednesday that costs tied to tariffs are projected to ding earnings by $100 million in its current fiscal year.  Estee Lauder added it will try to offset “more than half” of the levies by leveraging trade programs and optimizing its supply chain.

headline: Your Cosmetics To Get Expensive As Estée Lauder Anticipates $100 Million In Tariffs
summary: Estée Lauder Companies, Inc. (NYSE:EL) shares plummeted in the premarket session on Wednesday after the company reported fourth-quarter results. The company reported adjusted earnings per share of 9 cents, which is in line with the street view. Quarterly sales of $3.41 billion (down 12% year over year) outpaced the analyst consensus estimate of $3.397 billion. headline: Estée Lauder (NYSE:EL) Posts Q2 Sales In Line With Estimates But Stock Drops 10.5%
summary: Beauty products company Estée Lauder (NYSE:EL) met Wall Street’s revenue expectations in Q2 CY2025, but sales fell by 11.9% year on year to $3.41 billion. Its non-GAAP profit of $0.09 per share was in line with analysts’ consensus estimates.

headline: Estee Lauder: Fiscal Q4 Earnings Snapshot
summary: The average estimate of 11 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research was for earnings of 8 cents per share. The beauty products company posted revenue of $3.41 billion in the period, also exceeding Street forecasts. Nine analysts surveyed by Zacks expected $3.4 billion.

raw.headline: Estee Lauder: Fiscal Q4 Earnings Snapshot
raw.summary: The average estimate of 11 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research was for earnings of 8 cents per share. The beauty products company posted revenue of $3.41 billion in the period, also exceeding Street forecasts. Nine analysts surveyed by Zacks expected $3.4 billion.

headline: Estee Lauder forecasts profit below estimates, warns of $100 million tariff hit
summary: The Trump administration's unpredictable trade policies have put a strain on businesses that are grappling with higher costs and low demand.  To revive sales, Estee Lauder has been accelerating new launches in categories including skincare, introducing new luxury price tiers, increasing investments and implementing cost-savings measures, under new CEO Stephane de La Faverie, who took up the top job earlier this year.  In May, Estee Lauder said it was planning to reduce its sourcing in China from U.S. plants to below 10% by shifting production to Japan and Europe to counter over half of the expected hit from trade policies.

raw.headline: Estee Lauder forecasts profit below estimates, warns of $100 million tariff hit
raw.summary: The Trump administration's unpredictable trade policies have put a strain on businesses that are grappling with higher costs and low demand.  To revive sales, Estee Lauder has been accelerating new launches in categories including skincare, introducing new luxury price tiers, increasing investments and implementing cost-savings measures, under new CEO Stephane de La Faverie, who took up the top job earlier this year.  In May, Estee Lauder said it was planning to reduce its sourcing in China from U.S. plants to below 10% by shifting production to Japan and Europe to counter over half of the expected hit from trade policies.
